subject: Replace loopingcall in notifier with a delayed send
commit_message:
Replace loopingcall in notifier with a delayed send

The loopingcall thread here was started before processes fork and so
the thread stops working after the fork call.  This is a problem that
will probably need to be worked out in the long run.

To ensure that this notifier works correctly in all processes, this
change replaces the persistent loopingcall thread with a thread
created on demand to delay and batch up notifications.  The first
notification will trigger spawning the thread to wait to send it.  Any
notifications that come in the meantime will notice that there is
already a thread waiting to send and will return without spawning.

Conflicts:
        neutron/notifiers/nova.py

Change-Id: I519d4e89b8cee341c0e1cfffbce3e77151e8202a
Closes-Bug: #1301035

subject: Fixes arguments parsing when executing command
commit_message:
Fixes arguments parsing when executing command

A regression was caused by changing the eventlet.subprocess.Popen
with the builtin subprocess.Popen (by using the nova.utils execute
method) without changing the way the arguments were parsed.

In the v1 volume utilities module, the execution args were parsed
separated by whitespaces, which is not allowed by the builtin
subprocess.Popen, causing a "not found" error.

This error is returned for example when attaching a volume, at the
point where iscsicli tool is used to login the iSCSI target or portal.

This patch fixes the issue by simply splitting the args.

    * deprecating a default policy make the policy with the lowest index default

subject: Remove admin_metadata from regular users view
commit_message:
Remove admin_metadata from regular users view

Recently it was observed that with large numbers of volumes
that things like "cinder list" could take extremely long to
return.

For example, running cinder list on a system with 1000 volumes took
greater than 30 seconds to return.  It turns out that the cause of
this is the addition of visible admin_metadata.

There's two problems with this:
1. The original patch probably shouldn't have gone in
   data is either admin data or it's not, selectively picking
   pieces of admin data out to provide to the user just creates
   complications and introduces confusion.
2. The REAL issue here is that since the standar gets are made
   with the standard user context, the add_visible_admin_metadata
   would go through and do an elevated context get on every single
   volume individually.  This is what caused the horrible performance
   issue on cinder list with large numbers of volumes.

Running as admin, or removing the second call drops this down to about 3
seconds for the same 1000 volume list.

This patch removes the secondary admin context get_call.  Instead where
we expect to do display the visible admin_meta, we go ahead and elevate
the context so the returned object actually has the right entries.

This creates some issues with migration views, which are set to key
on is_admin context.  To fix that we introduce a flag to the get_all
call that tells the migration code if this is REALLY in fact an admin
and thus preseving the behavior.

For now, to fix the performance issue and offer a clean backport we're
going to keep the viewable admin_meta, however long term this needs to
be revisited.

Finally; the V2 API was refactored to use a common add_visible_metadata
method to cinder.utils.py.  Sadly however V1 wasn't updated to use this.
Since this method needed changed and was the root of the bug, this patch
also refactors the V1 code to use the same cinder.utils method as V2.

subject: Container Confict on obj update with wrong Storage-Policy-Index
commit_message:
Container Confict on obj update with wrong Storage-Policy-Index

The container server knows its storage policy index by looking in the
container_stat table.  When an object update comes in to the container server,
there is an X-Storage-Policy-Index header in the incoming request, or it's
implicitly 0 during an upgrade. If the submitted X-Storage-Policy-Index
doesn't match the container's policy index, reject the request with a 409
Conflict response.

By doing this, we ensure that we know the policy of every object in a
container: it's the same as the container. If it doesn't match, it doesn't get
in. This makes reconciling two disagreeing container DBs possible.

Additionally we encode the policy index into the pending file to maintain
speed in put_object without having to acctually open the database and check
the storage policy in the stats table.  Benchmarking showed the extra get_info
call in put_object slowed the operation down by ~70%.  In this implementation
the storage_policy_index is only checked when a) creating the .pending_file
that doesn't already exist and b) merging the .pending_file.  Since the file
is truncated at merge (rather than removed) this is a onetime setup for the
database before put_object can start streaming in.  This change requires
_commit_puts to know the location of the pending file, and a base
implementation to move the .pending_file attribute to a property was added to
the common DatabaseBroker.  In the base implementation it's just a passthrough
to the existing base ._pending_file attribute.  For the ContainerBroker every
time commit_puts is called we poll the stats table to lookup the
storage_policy_index.  Because the commit_puts call is expected to hit the
stats table anyway during triggers this change was expected to not have
noticable impact on merge throughput and indeed benchmarking confirmed.

Implements: blueprint storage-policies

Reprogram flows when ovs-vswitchd restarts

When OVS is restarted, by default it will not reprogram flows which were
programmed. For the case of the OVS agent, this means a restart will cause
all traffic to be switched using the NORMAL action. This is undesirable for
a number of reasons, including obvious security reasons.

This change provides a way for the agent to check if a restart of ovs-vswitchd
has happened in the main agent loop. If a restart of ovs-vswitchd is detected,
the agent will run through the setup of the bridges on the host and reprogram
flows for all the ports connected.

single 'drop' flow. This is used to monitor OVS restarts and to reprogram

In preparation for proposing the meat of storage policies to
master, we're taking small and harmless portions that may not
always appear to add value now but they will when storage
policies come in and geting them in now will minimize the size
of upcoming merges.

In this change, we're changing the name of ASYNCDIR to
ASYNCDIR_BASE as policies will have multiple async directory
names (one per policy).  In the object updater rather than just
looking for the one name 'asyncdir' we set the stage for looping
on all subdirs looking for things that start with ASYNCDIR_BASE
and moving on to the next dir if its not a match.  Introduction
of this code to master now adds no new functionality; one small
block of code will be merged later to actually match on names

subject: Allow any attributes in mapping and include in results
commit_message:
Allow any attributes in mapping and include in results

When using attribute mapping (e.g., user_additional_attribute_mapping), any
attributes that Keystone didn't know about were ignored and a warning was
issued, like

 WARNING keystone.common.ldap.core [-] Invalid additional attribute mapping:
 "description:description". Value "description" must use one of password,
 enabled, default_project_id, name, email.

This check is removed. Additional attribute mappings for "unexpected"
attributes (such as description) should be allowed. For one thing, all the
known attributes already have a way of setting the mapping, via the
user_*_attribute config option. This will allow setting a "description" or
any other attribute mapping for users.

The extra attributes defined in the *_additional_attribute_mapping config
options weren't included in the list results. These attributes should be

Consider free disk space before downloading images into cache

While it would be better to have this code in ImageCache itself,
by keeping it in PXE module we have the ability to clean up
both caches, not only current one, thus reclaiming more space.
We clean up instance image cache first, because:
1. It's probably larger
2. Instance images are not required for running instances,
   so they are more likely to be cleaned

In the follow-up patch I'll implement hints for clean_up()
call on how much space we need. Otherwise clean_up procedure
may think that nothing needs to be cleaned even though
we don't have enough space for new downloads.

This patch also adds ironic.common.images.download_size() helper

subject: Create missing domains during Bind9Backend start
commit_message:
Create missing domains during Bind9Backend start

The Bind9Backend start function uses rndc to reload each domain.  If a
domain is missing on the Bind9 server, a ProcessExecutionError will be
raised.  This bug was recreated by stopping a bind9 process, deleting
the cached nzf files in /var/cache/bind, and restarting the process.
The Designate Central service was then restarted, and the bug triggered.

The original bug report requested that the Bind9Backend check for zones
on the server before trying to reload them, but rndc does not appear to
support that operation.

A less ideal approach is used:  the start function will now catch
ProcessExecutionError exceptions and issue a command to recreate the
zone if the caught exception indicates that the zone was not found.

Another alternative approach could use standard DNS query tools rather
than rndc to confirm zone existence.

subject: Use Emacs-friendly file variable to set file encoding
commit_message:
Use Emacs-friendly file variable to set file encoding

Like Python, Emacs can read the file encoding from the first two
lines. Python will accept a line with

  -*- encoding: <some-encoding> -*-

since it looks for containing "coding:" or "coding=" (PEP 263) and
allows substring matches. Emacs only accepts

  -*- coding: <some-encoding> -*-

since it looks for a file variable named "coding", not "encoding":

  https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/emacs/Specify-Coding.html

Setting a variable called "encoding" has at best no effect, but it can
result in Emacs prompting the user with

  The local variable list in __init__.py contains values that may not
  be safe.

when opening the file. This is because the "encoding" variable is not
whitelisted as a safe variable.

The command used to update the files were:

  sed -i '1,2s/-\*- encoding:/-*- coding:/' **/*.py

This accounts for the case where the file variables is set in the
second line because the first line is used for a "#!" line.

This patch disables validation of stack parameters values when
loading existing stacks from the database. The old behavior was
to always validate stack parameter values when initializing a

custom constraints when a constraint could be fulfilled during

subject: auth_token middleware hashes tokens with configurable algorithm
commit_message:
auth_token middleware hashes tokens with configurable algorithm

The auth_token middleware always hashed PKI Tokens with MD5. This
change makes it so that PKI tokens can be hashed with SHA256 or any
other algorithm supported by hashlib.new(). This is for security
hardening.

auth_token has a new config option 'hash_algorithms' that is set
to the list of algorithms that will be used for hashing PKI tokens.
This will typically be set to a single hash algorithm which must
match the hash algorithm set in Keystone. Otherwise the tokens
in the revocation list will not match, leading to revoked tokens
being still usable.

During a transition from one algorithm to another,
'hash_algorithms' is set to both the new algorithm and the old
algorithm. Both of the hash algorithms will be used to match
against the revocation list and cache. Once the tokens using the
old algorithm have expired the old algorithm can be removed from
the list.

'hash_algorithms' defaults to ['md5'] for backwards compatibility.

DocImpact
SecurityImpact
Closes-Bug: #1174499

Change-Id: Ie524125dc5f6f1076bfd47db3a414b178e4dac80

subject: Set onlink routes for all subnets on an external network
commit_message:
Set onlink routes for all subnets on an external network

The addition of the on-link routes gives us some freedom to allocate a
router's IP address from any one of multiple subnets on one external
network.  Different routers can get their IPs from different subnets and
they still have direct on-link connectivity to each other.  For example,
one router with its primary IP from 10.0.0.0/24 and another from
192.168.0.0/24 can communicate directly.  It is important that each
router has on-link routes to *all* of the subnets.

Any router can host floating ips from any of the subnets regardless of
which subnet the primary IP address comes from.

This is an alternative to the "Multiple floating IP pools" section in
the administration guide.  It is a simpler alternative that avoids
having to create multiple external networks.  It is also more flexible
because routers will no longer be restricted to getting floating IPs
from the pool to which they happen to be connected.

DocImpact
Document the procedure for adding subnets to the external network.
Potentially remove the existing procedure for "Multiple floating IP
pools" from the docs.

subject: Nasty hack to work around pip's case-sensitivity
commit_message:
Nasty hack to work around pip's case-sensitivity

When pip is using an index url that uses http:// or https://, it will
respond to a 404 by searching a bit harder for variantCase versions of
the package name. This is very handy, results in pip appearing to be
case insensitive, and is relied on by many packages which simply specify
their dependencies in all lowercase regardless of the actual case of the
package.

When the index url uses file:// instead, no exception is handled -
instead the script simply dies once it fails to stat a file on disk.

This is only needed until
https://github.com/jamezpolley/pip/compare/pypa:develop...develop lands
upstream in pip. That patch adds an exception handler which catches the
fail to stat and generates a 404 Response object, which lets the same
handling code that triggers in the http:// case handle failures in the
file:// case as well.

We first hit this problem because of the MarkupSafe package being
specified as markupsafe in Jinja2's requirements.txt. This has been
fixed in
https://github.com/mitsuhiko/jinja2/commit/70a2bc0e58c211bdd86e89abd29ec12b2387b6fa#diff-2eeaed663bd0d25b7e608891384b7298
but this change does not seem to have been released yet.

This doesn't even approach a sensible fix; but since we expect the
problem to be fixed upstream shortly; and since this is the only known
occurrence of this problem (to me at least), this is a tiny little hack
that gets us out of a temporary bind and will be trivial to revert.

Closes bug: #1301220
